criticalSuccess: The moment you focus on the question, knowledge floods your mind like pages from a well-studied tome. Your training has prepared you perfectly for this. Whether it's formal education, hard-won experience, dedicated research, or natural aptitude, you have genuine expertise in this area. Details crystallize in your memory with perfect clarity. You don't just remember disconnected facts - you understand the complete picture. Strengths and weaknesses. Behaviors and patterns. Properties and relationships. Historical context and current implications. Your recall is comprehensive, nuanced, and absolutely reliable. You can speak with confidence and authority because your knowledge is thorough and accurate. This is exactly the kind of expertise that makes the difference between success and failure!

Like a scholar accessing a mental library, you draw on your extensive knowledge with perfect precision. Your mind makes immediate connections, pulling together information from multiple sources - lessons learned, texts studied, experiences lived. The knowledge that surfaces isn't just accurate, it's comprehensive. You understand not just what, but why and how. This is mastery of the subject matter, and it shows. You have the detailed, reliable information needed to make informed decisions!
success: You focus your mind on the question, and after a moment's concentration, relevant knowledge surfaces. Your training has touched on this subject, and you remember enough to be helpful. The information isn't exhaustive or perfectly detailed, but it's accurate and useful. You recall pertinent facts that provide valuable context and insight.

Your memory provides solid information. You draw on what you've learned through study or experience, and useful knowledge comes to mind. It's not comprehensive expertise, but it's reliable information that should prove helpful in understanding the current situation.
failure: You concentrate, searching your memory for any relevant knowledge, but come up completely empty. You sift through lessons learned, experiences lived, texts read - but nothing connects to this particular subject. Either your education never covered this area, or you've forgotten what you once knew. You rack your brain, trying to force the information to surface, but there's nothing there. You simply don't know about this. Sometimes ignorance is the honest answer, and this is one of those times.

Despite your best mental efforts, no useful knowledge surfaces. You try to remember - focusing, concentrating, searching every corner of your education and experience - but nothing relevant appears. This subject is outside your area of expertise or beyond your current recall. You draw a frustrating blank.
criticalFailure: Your mind provides information with absolute confidence - clear, detailed, seemingly accurate knowledge that feels completely true. There's just one catastrophic problem: it's all wrong. Whether it's a corrupted memory, confused facts from different subjects, or pure fabrication that your brain has accepted as truth, you now 'remember' false information with complete certainty. Your memory has presented lies as facts, and you have no reason to doubt them. This is worse than knowing nothing - you're misinformed and confident about it. If you act on this false 'knowledge,' the results could be disastrous. Your brain has betrayed you with convincing fiction!

Disaster strikes in the form of false certainty. You recall information that seems absolutely accurate - it has every quality of genuine knowledge except one: truth. Your memory has provided detailed, plausible, completely incorrect information, and you believe every word of it. This isn't a vague uncertainty - you're confident you know the facts. Unfortunately, everything you 'know' is wrong. This kind of confident misinformation is dangerous because you'll act on it without hesitation. Your memory has failed you in the worst possible way!
